abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Technical Assistance
            (TA) Project for Economic Reform is rated as satisfactory.
            The main lessons learned are: 1) In uncertain environments,
            project design should be based on the economic/institutional
            work and not over specify project activities. 2) Reform can
            go awry without properly done studies. 3) All sub-Project
            Implementing Units need adequate training for in the
            administrative aspects of implementation. 4) It is important
            for all implementing agencies to be commited to concerted
            and prompt implementation. 5) Flexible, stand alone TAs can
            be a crucial resource in transition economies. 6) The
            disadvantage of a tight timetable is the increased
            likelihood of the need for extensions of project closing
            date in order to accomplish project objectives. This
            disadvantage is acceptable if the tight timetable helps
            focus the country on the needed reforms and other
            commitments at a time when there is economy adversity. 7)
            Implementation flexibility is important to maximize
            effectiveness of loan proceeds. 8) Firm stance on extensions
            often heightens compliance with subsequent agreements. 9)
            Umbrella TA projects are expensive to supervise because of
            their many components and activities.
